qas.question: In what year did Reprise plan to release a series of 78 rpm singles?
Which disc did Reprise release in 78 rpm format?

answers.text: Think It's Going to Rain Today

qas.question: What two songs were featured on the 1978 release by Leon Redbone in 78 rpm format?

answers.text: Alabama Jubilee and Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone

qas.question: What record company released recordings of 'Buena' and 'Tuff Enuff' in 1980?
Why did Reprise only release one 78 rpm vinyl?

answers.text: lack of sales for the single, and a lack of general interest

context: In <a0_0>1968<a0_0/>, Reprise planned to release a series of 78 rpm singles from their artists on their label at the time, called the Reprise Speed Series. Only one disc actually saw release, Randy Newman's I <a1_0>Think It's Going to Rain Today<a1_0/>, a track from his self-titled debut album (with The Beehive State on the flipside). Reprise did not proceed further with the series due to a <a4_0>lack of sales for the single, and a lack of general interest<a4_0/> in the concept. Guitarist & vocalist Leon Redbone released a promotional 78 rpm record in 1978 featuring two songs (<a2_0>Alabama Jubilee and Please Don't Talk About Me When I'm Gone<a2_0/>) from his Champagne Charlie album. In 1980 <a3_0>Stiff Records<a3_0/> in the United Kingdom issued a 78 by Joe "King" Carrasco containing the songs Buena (Spanish for "good," with the alternate spelling "Bueno" on the label) and Tuff Enuff. Underground comic cartoonist and 78 rpm record collector Robert Crumb released three discs with his Cheap Suit Serenaders in the 1980s.
